Also missing documentation in Redfish.md
Documented common error.  you're recreating functions that already exists in sensor.hpp.  please look at how the existing sensor things determine this, and make yours similar.

> you're recreating functions that already exists in sensor.hpp.

Sorry, I am not following. could you please explain more?

Hi, rule 12 
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/COMMON_ERRORS.md#12-imprecise-matching

Use sdbusplus::message::object_path instead

It's not just rule 12 here.  The core issue here is that we have code that does this lookup performantly, using the existing associations, and correctly to dbus interfaces that was ignored and rewritten from scratch.  If new code is truly required (which I'm not convinced it is) that's fine, but it needs to be doing essentially the same operation.
Acknowledged
nit, handle, not handler
Done
Old style of logging, see https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/51587/23/http/http_client.hpp
Ack
Common error.  Non trivial lambda
Done
This should only be looking under the appropriate type in the object path.

> This should only be looking under the appropriate type in the object path.

you mean: /xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_tach & /xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/temperature & /xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_pwm ？
Yes, defined in https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Sensor/Value.interface.yaml#L13
Acknowledged
Can you call out the associations you are using to make this work?
Acknowledged
Please go through and unresolve comments that you've only ACKed

Why do you need the ret? 
Do just: 
"return true;"
Removed this function.
Can you "return false" ?
Removed this function.
non trivial lambda.
Acknowledged

I see nothing in this patchset that's creating this as an array or calling emplace_back/push_back, which makes me believe that this test result is from another system, and not a result of this patchset.  Is it possible that this patchset wasn't actually tested?

NO, we tested it and Validator passed.

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/65286/7/redfish-core/lib/thermal_metrics.hpp#34
This is an array, but the writing method is different. I have updated it in the new patch as per your comment.
just wrap your json in triple backticks.  No need to add line breaks in a json statement.
Done

This is an array of objects.  You need to call out the properties you've implemented

TemperatureReadingCelcius/Reading

etc.
Done
You call this tempArray, but it isn't an array?  Maybe you meant tempObject?  I would expect this to be an array.
Acknowledged
Please don't resolve comments that aren't done.  Go through and reopen the ones that aren't complete.
Done
Isn't this incorrect.  Sensor Ids include the name and type.  Did this link work in your testing?

Please answer my question.  Did you test that the links your code produced were correct?

You're quoting a DTMF example (which is not the specification) that was not taken on an openbmc system.  "SysBrdTemp" in the example is a uri segment that the server has control over, and on openbmc, doesn't match the example you've given.

I would expect that your tests would fail, which is why I'm asking if they were run recently.  If they're not failing, then I'm misunderstanding something.

> Please answer my question.  Did you test that the links your code produced were correct?

Yes, validator passed, and ran for a while on fp5280g3 and rainier.

> Did you test that the links your code produced were correct?

I didn't ask if the validator passed.  I asked if you tested the links.  The validator doesn't test DataSourceUri links.

"This property shall contain the name of the device associated with this sensor."

This doesn't look correct to that description, as you're putting in the sensor odata.id, not the device name.  Please remove.
Acknowledged
not resolved.
Removed `DeviceName` on patch-9.

Lots of this method looks incorrect.  Can we just use the same method that we use in sensors.hpp?

sensors::handleSensorGet

That seems like a good idea to share code to avoid problems like the above.

> Lots of this method looks incorrect.

Could you please point out what exactly is incorrect?

> sensors::handleSensorGet

I checked this method, but I do not know how to implement `DeviceName` and `Reading`. I do not think we can use this method instead.

> > Lots of this method looks incorrect.
> 

Compare your code to handleSensorGet, and you will see some very obvious differences in how the properties are generated.

> 
> > sensors::handleSensorGet
> 
> I checked this method, but I do not know how to implement `DeviceName` and `Reading`. I do not think we can use this method instead.

handleSensorGet doesn't currently implement DeviceName, so I'm not sure why that relates.  I would assume that DeviceName would need to be implemented in handleSensorGet, FIRST, before we could use it in ThermalSubsystem.

How to implement `TemperatureReadingsCelsius` in `handleSensorGet` method?

Yes, they do have similarities, but the properties they expose are completely different. Why use this method instead?

If there is a problem with the current logic, please point it out. At least for now, handleSensorGet is not a universal method.

> How to implement `TemperatureReadingsCelsius` in `handleSensorGet` method?

Add a method call arg called excerpt, that here is true, and in the other code is false.  Then, within that code, branch where appropriate such that the "excerpt" of the sensor is produced.

> 
> Yes, they do have similarities, but the properties they expose are completely different. Why use this method instead?

They're based on the same schema.  What do you mean the properties they produce are completely different?

> 
> If there is a problem with the current logic, please point it out. At least for now, handleSensorGet is not a universal method.

I'm avoiding pointing out the logic errors, because it will miss the fact that we've completely rewritten something that produces the same schema.  if we agree that we should write completely new code for this, at that point in time I will start pointing out the issues in this patchset, but given that it will likely all be condensed into sensor.hpp and associated sensor utils, that seems like a waste of effort.
depth 1.
Done
Do you mean to use the 3 single quotation marks instead of double quotation marks?   (\`\`\`)
I think both double quotes and single quotes are OK. Is there any explicit provision that we must use single quotes?
I meant - did you try to use triple backticks (\`\`\`), rather than triple quotes?
nit, just declare as nlohmann::json::object_t

Most of the other places, use `subtree' here.
Isn't it better to use it as common?
```
const dbus::utility::MapperGetSubTreeResponse& subtree
```

I will update all comments after this patch is merged:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/69008
Done
Wouldn't this be better with `BMCWEB_LOG_ERROR`?
Done

there's nothing checking that the other end of this is a sensor.  In this case, maybe we don't need to?  I'm not sure on that one, but given that's a problem on a bunch of the other patches, it's worth discussing.
Please answer in your commit message why this is useful, as opposed to just using SensorCollection.
Do we need any new unit tests here?
